nodes.bodyText: I noticed this in other JSON files aswell. Are these files from upstream somewhere or authored? This is not valid JSON (there is no comment in JSON (rfc7159)).
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@
+// See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
+// for the documentation about the tasks.json format

nodes.bodyText: This is what one gets when generating a skeletal VSCode project. Looks like these .json files accept comments, surprising - I might have used that instead of 2413e8b
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@
+// See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
+// for the documentation about the tasks.json format

nodes.bodyText: Ok - for me the important part is, that VSCode generates it so. I was just wondering why invalid JSON was created, but it seems web developers again ignored RFCs and invented a new format.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@
+// See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
+// for the documentation about the tasks.json format

nodes.bodyText: This looks a bit strange - is this intended, that this invocation silently drops the execution of the runnable? I would be a bit surprised if trying to debug.

Yes, the method invokeLaterWithUI is used to change cursor on main JFrame of the application. That yields an exception in headless mode. Not mangling the cursor shape - e.g. skipping the runnable - is exactly what is needed in headless mode.

Understood - when I first read the method name, I assumed, that is intended to invoke the Runnable on the EDT. That made me wonder why SwingUtilities#invokeLater was not used, which led to me reading the method.
